title: What are the best introductory and 'must-read' books on philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Essays and Aphorisms by Arthur Schopenhauer His work was often concerned with the “will”–our inner drives and power. “For that which is otherwise quite indigestible, all affliction, vexation, loss, grief, time alone digests.” But he also talks about surprisingly current issues: “Newspapers are the second hand of history”–and that the hand is often broken or malfunctioning. And of course, the timeless as well: “Hope is the confusion of the desire for a thing for its probability.” Nature and Selected Essays by Ralph Waldo EmersonEmerson’s essays make us act. They remind us that we are ultimately responsible for our own life, for making ethical choices and for fulfilling our potential. Man’s Search for Meaning by Viktor FranklMan is sent to a concentration camp and finds some way for good to come of it. Finds some way to turn it into the ultimate metaphor for life: that we have little control over our circumstances, complete control over our attitude, and our ability to make meaning out of the things which happen to us .In Frankl’s case, we are lucky that he was a brilliant psychologist and writer and managed to turn all this into one of the most important books of the 20th century. I think constantly of his line about the man who asks, “What is the meaning of life?” The answer is that you don’t get to ask the question. Life is the one who asks and we must reply with our actions.”
Bertrand Russell - A History of Western Philosophyhttp://www.amazon.com/History-Western-Philosophy-Bertrand-Russell/dp/0671201581 Very comprehensive, yet accessible to the average person
